thread.title: H.S. girls tennis: Local squads come up just short in state tournament - Sports
thread.title_full: H.S. girls tennis: Local squads come up just short in state tournament - Sports - NorthJersey.com

author: BOB SHWALB
title: H.S. girls tennis: Local squads come up just short in state tournament - Sports
text:
Buy this photo CHRIS PEDOTA/STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER Leonia’s Liya Davidov en route to her semifinal win against Verona before an epic final. WEST WINDSOR – Of the 140 participants at Thursday’s Group Tennis Championships, only two were left playing.
All remaining eyes at Mercer County Park were focused on Court 8, as Leonia’s Liya Davidov and Shore’s Charlotte Roarty slugged it out to decide this year’s Group 1 team winner.
“If you couldn’t appreciate this, you probably shouldn’t be watching tennis,” Leonia coach Tim Cullen said.
The riveting match ended with Roarty taking a 2-6, 7-5, 6-3 decision, giving Shore a 3-2 victory.
Leonia’s two points came from third-singles Bianka Lieber and the first-doubles duo of Jessica Reich and Elise Kim.
Earlier in the day, Leonia topped Verona in the semifinals, 4-1, as Kate Lieber, Davidov and Bianka Lieber won in singles, and Reich and Kim won in first doubles.
Group 2 
After dusting West Essex by a 5-0 count in the semifinals, Ramapo faced the state’s second-ranked team from Holmdel and lost, 4-1.
In the semifinals, the Green Raiders got wins from the singles trio of Brianna Omar, Taylor Thum and Lauren Laino, and the doubles pairs of Liz Kogan/Nicolette Kogut and Ella Sinoway/Jolie Strauss.
Omar recorded her team’s only point in the finals with a straight-set win over Brianna Gibbs.
Group 3 
Northern Highlands dropped a 5-0 semifinal decision to the state’s top team that includes the state’s best player – Stephanie Schrage of Millburn.
Highlands’ third-singles Emily Hite won a team-best five games from opponent Joanna Atwater.
Group 4 
For the third straight season, Ridgewood lost in the semifinals, this time to Ridge, 3-2.
Ridgewood’s points came from Julia Yoon and Alex Absey, who won their first- and third-singles matches in straight sets.
In the past two seasons, the Maroons lost by the same margin and dropped a decisive super tiebreaker. The Maroons had a 2-1 lead before dropping a pair of super tiebreakers.
